entries.title: Testing In React
entries.entryText: This would be a lot easier to type out if it wasn't in a .json file to start with, someone should create something to make this easier. Like some sort of app.

entries.title: Saving the UserId as an Int
entries.entryText: Alright so far so good. But you need to make sure that the data is sent in the right type. Which is what this test is for.
This HOPEFULLY worked. But you know, who knows at this point. Let's see if we can leave the title blank.
This should be a fine example of a text entry. And there is a slight problem, this text field will keep expanding which isn't good fam.

entries.title: Starting my new Codepal
entries.entryText:
Looks like we got this new site that I can use to track how I'm learning. Well today I'm learning about

how to use CKeditor 5, which is a rich text editor. It allows you to type in this box and it will create

html for you, so that you can BOLD and Italicize your notes. 

Right now I need to learn how to edit the styling of the editor because if you're not careful it will grow

out of control. Which we don't want to happen. But I guess I'll go looking on the internet for the answer

and I bet I'll find them.

entries.title: Using CSS on CKeditor
entries.entryText: Let's see if this works you have to keep testing because sometimes you don't notice the bugs when you're just writing stuff by yourself. But now that you're having to work on stuff like this it's important to keep testing things. So this issue is that when we style this it's losing the wrap property that it has by default and that's what we need in the details page to make sure that it does look weird. The problem is that as a user it's weird to see your text editor expand. So we need to see how to have content wrap and still make the editor the right size.

Let's see what happens when I keep adding new stuff and let's see if it will become hidden at a certain point because I think that is what is going to happen based on what has been happening lately which is very annoying because It should only be pulling from the one style sheet that is in each folder. But for some reason it's overwriting the styles everywhere which is not what I want to have happen at all. But I can find out what's happening no doubt, because their is a large amount of info on the CKeditior online which is nice the bigger problem is how do we edit things that don't have defined classes and that will be the problem that we have to solve. Yay.

entries.title: Just getting started!
entries.entryText:
Looking forward to getting started! I've been wanting to learn how to program for a very long time. But today is the day to start. First we're just going to focus on learning basic HTML and CSS. But so far we've worked on how to structure an HTML page. So that it's easier to understand and read when updating the web page. We do this through using HTML Tags. Which can be tags like Head, Body, which hold a lot of information or smaller tags, like Div tags, which can help us divide a website even more. 

We also learned about w3schools and MDNdeveloper.mozilla.org which are great resources to help learn what certain tags are for.

entries.title: Learning Windows Terminal
entries.entryText: Today we started to learn how to use windows terminal. It's a little hard at first but it's getting easier. And somethings are faster to do with the terminal so that's really cool. Also you can use a bunch of cool themes! There are so many different colors! I found one really cool site that has a ton of themes. I really enjoy changing up which themes I'm using for my terminal, and sites like that one make it really easy to find fun themes to use.

entries.title: VS Code
entries.entryText: Today I really got into VS code, turns out there are HUNDREDS plug-ins that can help with everything. I really like Prettier because helps to format your code so that it is easier to go back and read your code. So that's one that I would highly recommend for everyone! Another really good one is Live Server, but you have to be careful when using Live Server. Sometimes Live Server will cause your app to update when it shouldn't, which isn't good if you are trying to test your buttons. So it's worth a google to see how to make Live Server ignore file types or the name of a folder. Like I learned how to make live server ignore my API folder. Another new one that I found (Thanks Madi!) it's called Todo Tree, which allows you to make comments in your code about where you need to write code! It's super easy to use! Highly recommend!

entries.title: JavaScript GO!
entries.entryText: Here we go! Let's learn some JS, so turns out that JS makes the internet work. Of course you also have HTML and CSS. But what makes the internet do all the super cool stuff? Yep JavaScript! So what are some of the things we really need to understand about JS? Well JS Objects are probably one of the best places to start. We use JS objects for BASICALLY everything, why? Because our world is made up of objects, shopping carts, cars, sweaters. And those objects are made up of other things. A shopping cart? Well it's got 4 wheels, it's got a handle. If you want to think about it, Const shoppingCart = { "Wheels": 4, “Handle”: True }, we can start to break down our real world of objects into parts of code to model the real world. Another thing that we need to know a lot about is arrays, arrays are a collection of data, which could be integers, strings, even, OBJECTS! Plus there are tons of built in Methods to help work with arrays, here's a good list I found!  So we should definitely learn more about those methods.

entries.title: React Library!
entries.entryText: Alright let's see how React works? Well it's kind of a library of components to help you make a, and get this, app that REACTS to the user. It's has a lot of support from other developers who have built plenty of react components. Which allows us to look at component libraries and pick out a design style that we like. But once we learn how react works we can go in and make changes to the components so that they work with our data structure or match our color scheme for our app. React is a great way to build UI that works QUICKLY which is my favorite thing about React. You can go read some documentation about how a component works, and then use it in your app. So rather than having to write a whole app from scratch you can pick a component that will fit into your app.

entries.title: CKeditor 5
entries.entryText:
CK Editor is a rich text editor. Which is basically like MS Word or Notepad. It you to BOLD things, or Italicize things. We can also add links which is really cool, because it means that we can make really helpful notes.

The CK Editor 5 is the editor that is being used in this app, which has a lot of good documentation but it is a pain to style in our app. But it gets the job done. We'll probably use a different rich text editor once we start rebuilding some parts of the app. Because this editor is almost impossible in it's current format to edit well.
